Levica z več kot 11.000 podpisi v podporo ukinitvi dopolnilnega zavarovanja
06 Nov 2019, 12:47 by STA

Levica in njeni podporniki so v DZ danes prinesli nekaj več kot 11.600 podpisov v podporo ukinitvi dopolnilnega zdravstvenega zavarovanja. Pristojna parlamentarna odbora namreč prav danes odločata o predlogu Levice za ukinitev tega zavarovanja, a za zdaj kaže, da ne bodo uspešni. Podpise so zbirali na terenu in prek spleta.



Foto: STA

LJUBLJANA > "Če poslanci koalicije in tudi drugi ne želijo poslušati Levice, naj vsaj prisluhnejo glasu ljudi, ki so podpisali peticijo in si želijo ukinitve dopolnilnega zavarovanja," je v izjavi medijem tik pred tem, ko so podpise prinesli v DZ, pozval vodja poslancev Levice Matej T. Vatovec.
Članica Levice Ana Štromajer je povedala, da so podpise zbirali predvsem z namenom, da vladi sporočijo, da so ljudje naklonjeni ukinitvi dopolnilnega zavarovanja. Zahtevali so, da se še letos sprejme zakon, ki ukinja položnice za dopolnilno zdravstveno zavarovanje, da se več deset milijonov evrov, ki gredo po njihovih ocenah letno za komercialne zavarovalnice, nameni za javno zdravstvo, in da se v zdravstveni sistem prispeva glede na materialni in socialni položaj posameznika.
Po 16 letih obljub politike za ukinitev dopolnilnega zavarovanja ima DZ po navedbah Vatovca danes možnost, da o tem odloča.
Odbor DZ za finance namreč pravkar razpravlja o predlogu Levice za ukinitev dopolnilnega zdravstvenega zavarovanja, popoldne bo to vprašanje obravnaval še odbor za zdravstvo. Koalicija je že napovedala, da bo predlog zavrnila, saj je minister za zdravje Aleš Šabeder predstavil svoj predlog ukinitve dopolnilnega zavarovanja, ki ga bo predvidoma vložila vlada.
Predlog je le prvi korak pri spremembah plačevanja zdravstvenega zavarovanja in predvideva ukinitev dopolnilnega zavarovanja ter uvedbo obvezne pavšalne dajatve, ki se bo stekala na Zavod za zdravstveno zavarovanje. Šele v drugem koraku ministrstvo napoveduje pripravo solidarnostne lestvice plačevanja.
Levica se za zdaj še ni izrekla, kako bo ravnala, ko bo ta predlog na parlamentarnih mizah. Medtem ko koalicija vztraja, da je predlog ministrstva bolj finančno vzdržen kot predlog Levice, pa Vatovec zatrjuje, da je finančna vzdržnost predloga Levice tudi v času krize bolj trdna kot vzdržnost predloga ministrstva. Poleg tega slednji ne uvaja solidarnostnega plačevanja zavarovanja.
A današnje glasovanje o predlogu Levice bo usodno za njeno sodelovanje z vlado Marjana Šarca. Če bo koalicija predlog Levice danes zavrnila, bodo lahko le še ugotovili, da je vlada s tem dokončno odstopila od sporazuma o sodelovanju z njimi, je v torek povedal koordinator Levice Luka Mesec.
Napovedal je, da vsebinsko delovanje Levice odslej ne bo nič kaj drugačno in bodo ostali konstruktivna opozicija. Na očitke nekaterih v koaliciji, da s tem omogočajo nastanek desne vlade, pa je odgovoril, da "je ta vlada z določenimi potezami že močno skrenila v desno".

Left with more than 11,000 signatures in support of termination of supplementary insurance
06 Nov 2019, 12:47 by STA

The Left and its supporters today brought just over 11,600 signatures to the parliament to support the abolition of supplementary health insurance. Namely, the relevant parliamentary committees are now deciding on the Left's proposal to abolish this guarantee, but for now it appears that they will not be successful. The signatures were collected on the field and online.



Photo: STA

LJUBLJANA> "If coalition MPs and others do not want to listen to the Left, at least listen to the voice of the people who signed the petition and want the supplementary insurance to be canceled," the MP called in a statement to the media shortly before the signatures were brought to the National Assembly. Levice Matej T. Vatovec.
Levica member Ana Štromajer said the signatures were collected primarily to inform the government that people were in favor of canceling supplementary insurance. They demanded that a law be abolished this year that abolishes supplementary health insurance bills, that tens of millions of euros, which they estimate annually for commercial insurers, be earmarked for public health and that they contribute to the health system in terms of material and the social position of the individual.
According to Vatovec, after 16 years of policy promises to abolish supplementary insurance, the National Assembly has the opportunity to decide on it today.
The parliamentary finance committee is just debating Levica's proposal to abolish supplementary health insurance, and the health committee will discuss the issue this afternoon. The coalition has already announced that it will reject the proposal, as Health Minister Ales Shabeder has presented his proposal to abolish supplementary insurance, which is expected to be filed by the government.
The proposal is only the first step in changes to the payment of health insurance and envisages the abolition of supplementary insurance and the introduction of a mandatory flat-rate benefit, which will be paid to the Health Insurance Institute. It is only in the second step that the Ministry announces the establishment of a solidarity payment scale.
The Left has not yet stated how it will act when this proposal is on parliamentary tables. While the coalition insists that the ministry's proposal is more financially sustainable than the Levica proposal, Vatovec argues that the financial sustainability of the Levica proposal is even stronger during the crisis than the sustainability of the ministry proposal. Moreover, the latter does not introduce solidarity payments for insurance.
But today's vote on the Left proposal will be fatal to its involvement with the government of Marjan Sarac. If the coalition rejects the Levica proposal today, they will only be able to conclude that the government has thus definitively withdrawn the agreement on cooperation with them, Levica coordinator Luka Mesec said on Tuesday.
He announced that the substantive actions of the Left would henceforth be no different and would remain a constructive opposition. He responded to some of the coalition's allegations that it would allow the right government to emerge, saying that "this government has already made some serious moves to the right."
